results.headline: Fantasies Without Bounds for a Lothario With Limits
results.summary_short: Crispin Hellion Glover’s planned trilogy of blatant weirdness continues with a second installment, “It Is Fine! Everything Is Fine.”
results.display_title: It is Fine! EVERYTHING IS FINE.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of It is Fine! EVERYTHING IS FINE.

results.headline: A Stocking-Stuffer Idea: Lots of Old Resentments
results.summary_short: “This Christmas” includes more family melodrama than all the holiday-homecoming flicks from the past decade combined.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of This Christmas

results.headline: Is That Music We Hear or a Tyke’s Beating Heart?
results.summary_short: To describe “August Rush” as a piece of shameless hokum doesn’t quite do justice to the potentially shock-inducing sugar content of this contemporary fairy tale.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of August Rush

results.headline: Beyond the Kitsch
results.summary_short: “The Life of Reilly” is built around “Save It for the Stage,” a one-man stage show by Charles Nelson Reilly, a showbiz gadfly and Tony Award-winning theater director.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Life of Reilly

results.headline: Rage, Fear and Revulsion: At War With the War
results.summary_short: Brian De Palma’s “Redacted” traffics in, and clearly means to provoke, strong, unbalanced emotions.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Redacted

results.headline: A Very Long Lunch Hour
results.summary_short: Suicide, infidelity, spousal abuse and arrested development are the building blocks of “Park,” a wearisome comedy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Park

results.headline: Dearly Beloved, We Are Gathered Here Today to Rend One Another Apart
results.summary_short: When it comes to emotional violence, “Margot at the Wedding” is hard to beat.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Margot at the Wedding

results.headline: Cherishing the Fantasy in 6-Year-Olds of All Ages
results.summary_short: If the concept of “Mr. Magorium’s Wonder Emporium” is ingenious, its execution is erratic.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mr. Magorium's Wonder Emporium

results.headline: A Tasty Road to Enlightenment
results.summary_short: A jaunty mix of chanting, baking and spiritual uplift, “How to Cook Your Life” introduces us to the cooking classes of Edward Espe Brown, a twinkling Zen priest.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of How to Cook Your Life

results.headline: 50 Years and 600 Women Later, True Love
results.summary_short: “Love in the Time of Cholera” is faithful to the outline of the novel but emotionally and spiritually anemic.
results.display_title: Love in the Time of Cholera

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Love in the Time of Cholera

results.headline: The Gospel of Stop Shopping
results.summary_short: At the very least, the documentary “What Would Jesus Buy?” might make a viewer think twice about that next purchase at the Gap.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of What Would Jesus Buy?

results.headline: Confronting the Fabled Monster, Not to Mention His Naked Mom
results.summary_short: You don’t need to wait for Angelina Jolie to rise from the vaporous depths naked to know that this “Beowulf” isn’t your high school teacher’s Old English epic poem.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beowulf

results.headline: Apocalypse Soon: A Mushroom Cloud Doesn’t Stall 2008 Electioneering
results.summary_short: “Southland Tales” is a funny, audacious, messy and feverishly inspired look at America and its discontents.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Southland Tales

results.headline: After 5 Decades, Still Igniting the Screen
results.summary_short: More than 50 years after its first screening in America, “Monika” arrives in New York again to light up the screen, this time without a trace of impropriety.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sommaren Med Monika

results.headline: Home Is Where the Heart Is, but Then the Heart Moves
results.summary_short: In “I for India” Sandhya Suri offers her family’s immigrant experience as a springboard for questions of nationality and  filial responsibility.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I for India

results.headline: He Found a Bundle of Money, and Now There’s Hell to Pay
results.summary_short: For formalists — those moviegoers sent into raptures by tight editing, nimble camera work and faultless sound design — “No Country for Old Men” is pure heaven.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of No Country for Old Men

results.headline: Musical Dreams After Nightmares
results.summary_short: “War/Dance” is an honorable, sometimes inspiring exploration of the primal healing power of music and dance in an African tribal culture.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of War/Dance

results.headline: Graphic Horrors and Private Dramas
results.summary_short: “Steal a Pencil for Me” recounts 93-year-old Holocaust survivor Jack Polak’s stint in Nazi camps.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Steal a Pencil for Me

results.headline: Repressed Desires and Sexual Frankness
results.summary_short: The off-putting, sometimes dizzying visual style of “The Sacred Family” settles down enough to reveal elements of absorbing drama.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sacred Family

results.headline: Dostoyevsky With Bollywood Style
results.summary_short: “Saawariya” is 2 hours 11 minutes  of wide-screen close-ups, fanciful sets, colorful costumes, bellybuttons, almost-kisses and 10 pumped-up, achingly sweet songs.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Saawariya
